replies.context: Dead dolphin and all you can do is joke.
And worst!
Dolphins are mammals, not fish.

Dolphins live in water. The taxonomic categories are man-made – they are artificial.

"And God said, Let the waters bring forth abundantly the moving creature that hath life, and fowl that may fly above the earth in the open firmament of heaven.
"And God created great whales, and every living creature that moveth, which the waters brought forth abundantly, after their kind, and every winged fowl after his kind: and God saw that it was good.
"And God blessed them, saying, Be fruitful, and multiply, and fill the waters in the seas, and let fowl multiply in the earth.
"And the evening and the morning were the fifth day.
– Genesis 1.20 - 23 (KJV)

Of course, you don't believe that narrative. You don't believe the God of the Bible. You blaspheme the Holy Spirit, the Author of the Bible.
No. ScienceRocks is correct. Dolphins are mammals even though they resemble fish. Your ancient book of mythology is wrong and your holy spirit only exists in your head.
Dolphins are not mentioned in the Bible, except in the class of all creatures that live in the sea. Dolphins live in the sea, do they not?
Dolphins are still mammals, and still not fish.

Of course, dolphins are mammals but that is still a man-invented label. We have chosen certain traits with which to group animals together. Other traits could have been chosen. It may make sense to it but it is, in fact, arbitrary.

The "mammal" label indicates that an animal feeds its offspring with milk, among other traits. I do not deny that. The "fish" label indicates a creature the breathes primarily water, with other traits necessary to isolate "fish" from, say, arthropoda, like a spine. I do not deny what fish are.

We choose to group animals together into categories based on shared traits. What I am saying is not primarily about biology so much as it is about language. Taxonomy is at its root a linguistic endeavor. It was the first task assigned to Adam. Adam was a scientist before he was a gardener.

The diversity of God's created creatures is just extraordinary!
Adam is a myth. He never existed.

Says you. Who the hell are you? 

You've been on this Earth only a few days and you don't even remember when or how you got here, and you think you know something? Pshaw.
I can look at the fossil evidence and see clearly that human's evolved for other primates. You have ZERO evidence that Adam ever existed other than your book of fairytales.

You've been on this Earth only a few days and you don't even remember when or how you got here.

You have never even handled a human fossil. What's your epistemology? What makes you think you know anything? You're a high school graduate who believes the stories he's been told – nothing more.
College graduate and I HAVE handled human fossils. Do you enjoy being wrong about EVERYTHING?

The taxonomic system we use is FAR from "arbitrary."
That you can make such an outlandish claim simply demonstrates your complete ignorance of the system.

Why do we not group all creatures that live in the sea together. That’s an obviously shared trait. The taxonomy system is a product of human pattern recognition but no creature comes with a tag that says “mammal” or “vertebrae.” The primary task of a scientist is taxonomy — to identify traits and categorize and name things. The nuclear physicist identifies subatomic particles, discerns their properties and names them. The astronomer identifies different types of astronomical objects and describes and names them. The biologist has this relationship with living things. Some so-called “scientific” endeavors are not science at all — like paleontology. Many, many scientific fields are filled with nothing but undemonstrable conjecture. There is a place for that in the human experience but it is not rightly called “science.”

Okay, I don't have time to rip to shreds your every illogical comment (i.e. all of them.) But since you are now a delusional purveyor of what constitutes science, let me ask you this:
Do you think that it would be useful to biological science to link together sea urchins, starfish, catfish, sharks, and dolphins all in the same category, just because they live in the oceans?
The taxonomic system we have was first published in 1758 by Swedish botanist Carl von Linne (Linnaeus). That was 100 years before Darwin and Wallace announced their then hypothesis, now confirmed theory, of biological evolution through natural selection. Yet the system works pretty well with evolution too, except at the species level which is more slippery than Linnaeus proposed.
One more question: Do you have any idea how much damage you people cause to Christianity and faith in general?

The strip mining pollution is the majority of the plastic is 3rd world countries the runoff is mostly from growing vegan food the copper strip mines are needed for all green electrical devices. Have you ever been to an offshore oil rig. If so you would know they are a haven for sea life

Toxic fertilizers are used MOST extensively in industrial farming operations around the world and cause the VAST majority of the runoff, and most of that farming is for animal feed, especially in the USA.
I've scuba dove on oil rigs and the stilts do indeed support sea life. The rigs also pollute the ocean in numerous small spills and MASSIVE catastrophic ones too, that kill far more sea life than all the rigs combined support.
